Text: Ah, stand by.

Text: Well then, sustain him: O!

Text: Most noble sir, arise; the queen approaches: Her head's declined, and death will seize her, but Your comfort makes the rescue.

Text: I have offended reputation, A most unnoble swerving.

Text: Sir, the queen.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O, whither hast thou led me, Egypt? See, How I convey my shame out of thine eyes By looking back what I have left behind 'Stroy'd in dishonour.

Text: O my lord, my lord, Forgive my fearful sails! I little thought You would have follow'd.

Text: Egypt, thou knew'st too well My heart was to thy rudder tied by the strings, And thou shouldst tow me after: o'er my spirit Thy full supremacy thou knew'st, and that Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods Command me.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O, my pardon!

Text: Now I must To the young man send humble treaties, dodge And palter in the shifts of lowness; who With half the bulk o' the world play'd as I pleased, Making and marring fortunes. You did know How much you were my conqueror; and that My sword, made weak by my affection, would Obey it on all cause.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Pardon, pardon!

Text: Fall not a tear, I say; one of them rates All that is won and lost: give me a kiss; Even this repays me. We sent our schoolmaster; Is he come back? Love, I am full of lead. Some wine, within there, and our viands! Fortune knows We scorn her most when most she offers blows.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Let him appear that's come from Antony. Know you him?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Caesar, 'tis his schoolmaster: An argument that he is pluck'd, when hither He sends so poor a pinion off his wing, Which had superfluous kings for messengers Not many moons gone by.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Approach, and speak.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Such as I am, I come from Antony: I was of late as petty to his ends As is the morn-dew on the myrtle-leaf To his grand sea.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Be't so: declare thine office.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and Requires to live in Egypt: which not granted, He lessens his requests; and to thee sues To let him breathe between the heavens and earth, A private man in Athens: this for him. Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness; Submits her to thy might; and of thee craves The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs, Now hazarded to thy grace.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: For Antony, I have no ears to his request. The queen Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she From Egypt drive her all-disgraced friend, Or take his life there: this if she perform, She shall not sue unheard. So to them both.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Fortune pursue thee!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Bring him through the bands. From Antony win Cleopatra: promise, And in our name, what she requires; add more, From thine invention, offers: women are not In their best fortunes strong; but want will perjure The ne'er touch'd vestal: try thy cunning, Thyreus; Make thine own edict for thy pains, which we Will answer as a law.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Caesar, I go.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Observe how Antony becomes his flaw, And what thou think'st his very action speaks In every power that moves.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Caesar, I shall.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What shall we do, Enobarbus?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Think, and die.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Is Antony or we in fault for this?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Antony only, that would make his will Lord of his reason. What though you fled From that great face of war, whose several ranges Frighted each other? why should he follow? The itch of his affection should not then Have nick'd his captainship; at such a point, When half to half the world opposed, he being The meered question: 'twas a shame no less Than was his loss, to course your flying flags, And leave his navy gazing.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Prithee, peace.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Is that his answer?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Ay, my lord.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The queen shall then have courtesy, so she Will yield us up.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: He says so.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Let her know't. To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head, And he will fill thy wishes to the brim With principalities.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: That head, my lord?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: To him again: tell him he wears the rose Of youth upon him; from which the world should note Something particular: his coin, ships, legions, May be a coward's; whose ministers would prevail Under the service of a child as soon As i' the command of Caesar: I dare him therefore To lay his gay comparisons apart, And answer me declined, sword against sword, Ourselves alone. I'll write it: follow me.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Unstate his happiness, and be staged to the show, Against a sworder! I see men's judgments are A parcel of their fortunes; and things outward Do draw the inward quality after them, To suffer all alike. That he should dream, Knowing all measures, the full Caesar will Answer his emptiness! Caesar, thou hast subdued His judgment too.

Text: A messenger from CAESAR.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What, no more ceremony? See, my women! Against the blown rose may they stop their nose That kneel'd unto the buds. Admit him, sir.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The loyalty well held to fools does make Our faith mere folly: yet he that can endure To follow with allegiance a fall'n lord Does conquer him that did his master conquer And earns a place i' the story.

Text: Caesar's will?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has; Or needs not us. If Caesar please, our master Will leap to be his friend: for us, you know, Whose he is we are, and that is, Caesar's.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: So. Thus then, thou most renown'd: Caesar entreats, Not to consider in what case thou stand'st, Further than he is Caesar.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Go on: right royal.

Text: O!

Text: He is a god, and knows What is most right: mine honour was not yielded, But conquer'd merely.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I will ask Antony. Sir, sir, thou art so leaky, That we must leave thee to thy sinking, for Thy dearest quit thee.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Shall I say to Caesar What you require of him? for he partly begs To be desired to give. It much would please him, That of his fortunes you should make a staff To lean upon: but it would warm his spirits, To hear from me you had left Antony, And put yourself under his shrowd, The universal landlord.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What's your name?

Text: My name is Thyreus.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Most kind messenger, Say to great Caesar this: in deputation I kiss his conquering hand: tell him, I am prompt To lay my crown at 's feet, and there to kneel: Tell him from his all-obeying breath I hear The doom of Egypt.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: 'Tis your noblest course. Wisdom and fortune combating together, If that the former dare but what it can, No chance may shake it. Give me grace to lay My duty on your hand.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Your Caesar's father oft, When he hath mused of taking kingdoms in, Bestow'd his lips on that unworthy place, As it rain'd kisses.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Favours, by Jove that thunders! What art thou, fellow?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: One that but performs The bidding of the fullest man, and worthiest To have command obey'd.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Approach, there! Ah, you kite! Now, gods and devils! Authority melts from me: of late, when I cried 'Ho!' Like boys unto a muss, kings would start forth, And cry 'Your will?' Have you no ears? I am Antony yet. Take hence this Jack, and whip him.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Than with an old one dying.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Moon and stars! Whip him. Were't twenty of the greatest tributaries That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them So saucy with the hand of she here,--what's her name, Since she was Cleopatra? Whip him, fellows, Till, like a boy, you see him cringe his face, And whine aloud for mercy: take him hence.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Mark Antony!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Tug him away: being whipp'd, Bring him again: this Jack of Caesar's shall Bear us an errand to him. You were half blasted ere I knew you: ha! Have I my pillow left unpress'd in Rome, Forborne the getting of a lawful race, And by a gem of women, to be abused By one that looks on feeders?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Good my lord,--

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: You have been a boggler ever: But when we in our viciousness grow hard-- O misery on't!--the wise gods seel our eyes; In our own filth drop our clear judgments; make us Adore our errors; laugh at's, while we strut To our confusion.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O, is't come to this?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I found you as a morsel cold upon Dead Caesar's trencher; nay, you were a fragment Of Cneius Pompey's; besides what hotter hours, Unregister'd in vulgar fame, you have Luxuriously pick'd out: for, I am sure, Though you can guess what temperance should be, You know not what it is.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Wherefore is this?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: To let a fellow that will take rewards And say 'God quit you!' be familiar with My playfellow, your hand; this kingly seal And plighter of high hearts! O, that I were Upon the hill of Basan, to outroar The horned herd! for I have savage cause; And to proclaim it civilly, were like A halter'd neck which does the hangman thank For being yare about him. Is he whipp'd?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Soundly, my lord.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Cried he? and begg'd a' pardon?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: He did ask favour.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: If that thy father live, let him repent Thou wast not made his daughter; and be thou sorry To follow Caesar in his triumph, since Thou hast been whipp'd for following him: henceforth The white hand of a lady fever thee, Shake thou to look on 't. Get thee back to Caesar, Tell him thy entertainment: look, thou say He makes me angry with him; for he seems Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am, Not what he knew I was: he makes me angry; And at this time most easy 'tis to do't, When my good stars, that were my former guides, Have empty left their orbs, and shot their fires Into the abysm of hell. If he mislike My speech and what is done, tell him he has Hipparchus, my enfranched bondman, whom He may at pleasure whip, or hang, or torture, As he shall like, to quit me: urge it thou: Hence with thy stripes, begone!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Have you done yet?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Alack, our terrene moon Is now eclipsed; and it portends alone The fall of Antony!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I must stay his time.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes With one that ties his points?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Not know me yet?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Cold-hearted toward me?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Ah, dear, if I be so, From my cold heart let heaven engender hail, And poison it in the source; and the first stone Drop in my neck: as it determines, so Dissolve my life! The next Caesarion smite! Till by degrees the memory of my womb, Together with my brave Egyptians all, By the discandying of this pelleted storm, Lie graveless, till the flies and gnats of Nile Have buried them for prey!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I am satisfied. Caesar sits down in Alexandria; where I will oppose his fate. Our force by land Hath nobly held; our sever'd navy too Have knit again, and fleet, threatening most sea-like. Where hast thou been, my heart? Dost thou hear, lady? If from the field I shall return once more To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood; I and my sword will earn our chronicle: There's hope in't yet.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: That's my brave lord!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I will be treble-sinew'd, hearted, breathed, And fight maliciously: for when mine hours Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives Of me for jests; but now I'll set my teeth, And send to darkness all that stop me. Come, Let's have one other gaudy night: call to me All my sad captains; fill our bowls once more; Let's mock the midnight bell.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: It is my birth-day: I had thought to have held it poor: but, since my lord Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: We will yet do well.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Call all his noble captains to my lord.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Do so, we'll speak to them; and to-night I'll force The wine peep through their scars. Come on, my queen; There's sap in't yet. The next time I do fight, I'll make death love me; for I will contend Even with his pestilent scythe.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Now he'll outstare the lightning. To be furious, Is to be frighted out of fear; and in that mood The dove will peck the estridge; and I see still, A diminution in our captain's brain Restores his heart: when valour preys on reason, It eats the sword it fights with. I will seek Some way to leave him.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: He calls me boy; and chides, as he had power To beat me out of Egypt; my messenger He hath whipp'd with rods; dares me to personal combat, Caesar to Antony: let the old ruffian know I have many other ways to die; meantime Laugh at his challenge.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Caesar must think, When one so great begins to rage, he's hunted Even to falling. Give him no breath, but now Make boot of his distraction: never anger Made good guard for itself.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Let our best heads Know, that to-morrow the last of many battles We mean to fight: within our files there are, Of those that served Mark Antony but late, Enough to fetch him in. See it done: And feast the army; we have store to do't, And they have earn'd the waste. Poor Antony!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: He will not fight with me, Domitius.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: No.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Why should he not?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune, He is twenty men to one.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: To-morrow, soldier, By sea and land I'll fight: or I will live, Or bathe my dying honour in the blood Shall make it live again. Woo't thou fight well?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I'll strike, and cry 'Take all.'

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Well said; come on. Call forth my household servants: let's to-night Be bounteous at our meal. Give me thy hand, Thou hast been rightly honest;--so hast thou;-- Thou,--and thou,--and thou:--you have served me well, And kings have been your fellows.

Text: And thou art honest too. I wish I could be made so many men, And all of you clapp'd up together in An Antony, that I might do you service So good as you have done.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The gods forbid!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Well, my good fellows, wait on me to-night: Scant not my cups; and make as much of me As when mine empire was your fellow too, And suffer'd my command.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Tend me to-night; May be it is the period of your duty: Haply you shall not see me more; or if, A mangled shadow: perchance to-morrow You'll serve another master. I look on you As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends, I turn you not away; but, like a master Married to your good service, stay till death: Tend me to-night two hours, I ask no more, And the gods yield you for't!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What mean you, sir, To give them this discomfort? Look, they weep; And I, an ass, am onion-eyed: for shame, Transform us not to women.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Ho, ho, ho! Now the witch take me, if I meant it thus! Grace grow where those drops fall! My hearty friends, You take me in too dolorous a sense; For I spake to you for your comfort; did desire you To burn this night with torches: know, my hearts, I hope well of to-morrow; and will lead you Where rather I'll expect victorious life Than death and honour. Let's to supper, come, And drown consideration.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Brother, good night: to-morrow is the day.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: It will determine one way: fare you well. Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Nothing. What news?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Belike 'tis but a rumour. Good night to you.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Well, sir, good night.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Soldiers, have careful watch.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: And you. Good night, good night.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Here we: and if to-morrow Our navy thrive, I have an absolute hope Our landmen will stand up.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: 'Tis a brave army, And full of purpose.

Text: No.

Text: Peace, I say! What should this mean?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: 'Tis the god Hercules, whom Antony loved, Now leaves him.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Walk; let's see if other watchmen Do hear what we do?

Text: How now, masters!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: How now! do you hear this?

Text: Ay; is't not strange?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Do you hear, masters? do you hear?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Content. 'Tis strange.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Eros! mine armour, Eros!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Sleep a little.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: No, my chuck. Eros, come; mine armour, Eros! Come good fellow, put mine iron on: If fortune be not ours to-day, it is Because we brave her: come.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Nay, I'll help too. What's this for?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Ah, let be, let be! thou art The armourer of my heart: false, false; this, this.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Sooth, la, I'll help: thus it must be.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Well, well; We shall thrive now. Seest thou, my good fellow? Go put on thy defences.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Briefly, sir.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Is not this buckled well?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Rarely, rarely: He that unbuckles this, till we do please To daff't for our repose, shall hear a storm. Thou fumblest, Eros; and my queen's a squire More tight at this than thou: dispatch. O love, That thou couldst see my wars to-day, and knew'st The royal occupation! thou shouldst see A workman in't. Good morrow to thee; welcome: Thou look'st like him that knows a warlike charge: To business that we love we rise betime, And go to't with delight.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: A thousand, sir, Early though't be, have on their riveted trim, And at the port expect you.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The morn is fair. Good morrow, general.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Good morrow, general.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: 'Tis well blown, lads: This morning, like the spirit of a youth That means to be of note, begins betimes. So, so; come, give me that: this way; well said. Fare thee well, dame, whate'er becomes of me: This is a soldier's kiss: rebukeable And worthy shameful cheque it were, to stand On more mechanic compliment; I'll leave thee Now, like a man of steel. You that will fight, Follow me close; I'll bring you to't. Adieu.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Please you, retire to your chamber.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Lead me. He goes forth gallantly. That he and Caesar might Determine this great war in single fight! Then Antony,--but now--Well, on.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The gods make this a happy day to Antony!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Would thou and those thy scars had once prevail'd To make me fight at land!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Hadst thou done so, The kings that have revolted, and the soldier That has this morning left thee, would have still Follow'd thy heels.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Who's gone this morning?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Who! One ever near thee: call for Enobarbus, He shall not hear thee; or from Caesar's camp Say 'I am none of thine.'

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What say'st thou?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Sir, He is with Caesar.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Go, Eros, send his treasure after; do it; Detain no jot, I charge thee: write to him-- I will subscribe--gentle adieus and greetings; Say that I wish he never find more cause To change a master. O, my fortunes have Corrupted honest men! Dispatch.--Enobarbus!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight: Our will is Antony be took alive; Make it so known.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Caesar, I shall.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The time of universal peace is near: Prove this a prosperous day, the three-nook'd world Shall bear the olive freely.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Antony Is come into the field.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Go charge Agrippa Plant those that have revolted in the van, That Antony may seem to spend his fury Upon himself.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Alexas did revolt; and went to Jewry on Affairs of Antony; there did persuade Great Herod to incline himself to Caesar, And leave his master Antony: for this pains Caesar hath hang'd him. Canidius and the rest That fell away have entertainment, but No honourable trust. I have done ill; Of which I do accuse myself so sorely, That I will joy no more.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Enobarbus, Antony Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with His bounty overplus: the messenger Came on my guard; and at thy tent is now Unloading of his mules.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I give it you.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Mock not, Enobarbus. I tell you true: best you safed the bringer Out of the host; I must attend mine office, Or would have done't myself. Your emperor Continues still a Jove.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I am alone the villain of the earth, And feel I am so most. O Antony, Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid My better service, when my turpitude Thou dost so crown with gold! This blows my heart: If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean Shall outstrike thought: but thought will do't, I feel. I fight against thee! No: I will go seek Some ditch wherein to die; the foul'st best fits My latter part of life.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Retire, we have engaged ourselves too far: Caesar himself has work, and our oppression Exceeds what we expected.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O my brave emperor, this is fought indeed! Had we done so at first, we had droven them home With clouts about their heads.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Thou bleed'st apace.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I had a wound here that was like a T, But now 'tis made an H.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: They do retire.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: We'll beat 'em into bench-holes: I have yet Room for six scotches more.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves For a fair victory.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Let us score their backs, And snatch 'em up, as we take hares, behind: 'Tis sport to maul a runner.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I will reward thee Once for thy spritely comfort, and ten-fold For thy good valour. Come thee on.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I'll halt after.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: We have beat him to his camp: run one before, And let the queen know of our gests. To-morrow, Before the sun shall see 's, we'll spill the blood That has to-day escaped. I thank you all; For doughty-handed are you, and have fought Not as you served the cause, but as 't had been Each man's like mine; you have shown all Hectors. Enter the city, clip your wives, your friends, Tell them your feats; whilst they with joyful tears Wash the congealment from your wounds, and kiss The honour'd gashes whole. Give me thy hand To this great fairy I'll commend thy acts, Make her thanks bless thee. O thou day o' the world, Chain mine arm'd neck; leap thou, attire and all, Through proof of harness to my heart, and there Ride on the pants triumphing!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Lord of lords! O infinite virtue, comest thou smiling from The world's great snare uncaught?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: My nightingale, We have beat them to their beds. What, girl! though grey Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha' we A brain that nourishes our nerves, and can Get goal for goal of youth. Behold this man; Commend unto his lips thy favouring hand: Kiss it, my warrior: he hath fought to-day As if a god, in hate of mankind, had Destroy'd in such a shape.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I'll give thee, friend, An armour all of gold; it was a king's.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: He has deserved it, were it carbuncled Like holy Phoebus' car. Give me thy hand: Through Alexandria make a jolly march; Bear our hack'd targets like the men that owe them: Had our great palace the capacity To camp this host, we all would sup together, And drink carouses to the next day's fate, Which promises royal peril. Trumpeters, With brazen din blast you the city's ear; Make mingle with rattling tabourines; That heaven and earth may strike their sounds together, Applauding our approach.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: If we be not relieved within this hour, We must return to the court of guard: the night Is shiny; and they say we shall embattle By the second hour i' the morn.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: This last day was A shrewd one to's.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O, bear me witness, night,--

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What man is this?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Stand close, and list him.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Be witness to me, O thou blessed moon, When men revolted shall upon record Bear hateful memory, poor Enobarbus did Before thy face repent!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Enobarbus!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Peace! Hark further.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O sovereign mistress of true melancholy, The poisonous damp of night disponge upon me, That life, a very rebel to my will, May hang no longer on me: throw my heart Against the flint and hardness of my fault: Which, being dried with grief, will break to powder, And finish all foul thoughts. O Antony, Nobler than my revolt is infamous, Forgive me in thine own particular; But let the world rank me in register A master-leaver and a fugitive: O Antony! O Antony!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Let's speak To him.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Let's hear him, for the things he speaks May concern Caesar.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Let's do so. But he sleeps.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Swoons rather; for so bad a prayer as his Was never yet for sleep.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Go we to him.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Awake, sir, awake; speak to us.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Hear you, sir?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The hand of death hath raught him. Hark! the drums Demurely wake the sleepers. Let us bear him To the court of guard; he is of note: our hour Is fully out.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Come on, then; He may recover yet.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Their preparation is to-day by sea; We please them not by land.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: For both, my lord.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I would they'ld fight i' the fire or i' the air; We'ld fight there too. But this it is; our foot Upon the hills adjoining to the city Shall stay with us: order for sea is given; They have put forth the haven Where their appointment we may best discover, And look on their endeavour.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: But being charged, we will be still by land, Which, as I take't, we shall; for his best force Is forth to man his galleys. To the vales, And hold our best advantage.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Yet they are not join'd: where yond pine does stand, I shall discover all: I'll bring thee word Straight, how 'tis like to go.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Swallows have built In Cleopatra's sails their nests: the augurers Say they know not, they cannot tell; look grimly, And dare not speak their knowledge. Antony Is valiant, and dejected; and, by starts, His fretted fortunes give him hope, and fear, Of what he has, and has not.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: All is lost; This foul Egyptian hath betrayed me: My fleet hath yielded to the foe; and yonder They cast their caps up and carouse together Like friends long lost. Triple-turn'd whore! 'tis thou Hast sold me to this novice; and my heart Makes only wars on thee. Bid them all fly; For when I am revenged upon my charm, I have done all. Bid them all fly; begone. O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more: Fortune and Antony part here; even here Do we shake hands. All come to this? The hearts That spaniel'd me at heels, to whom I gave Their wishes, do discandy, melt their sweets On blossoming Caesar; and this pine is bark'd, That overtopp'd them all. Betray'd I am: O this false soul of Egypt! this grave charm,-- Whose eye beck'd forth my wars, and call'd them home; Whose bosom was my crownet, my chief end,-- Like a right gipsy, hath, at fast and loose, Beguiled me to the very heart of loss. What, Eros, Eros! Ah, thou spell! Avaunt!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Why is my lord enraged against his love?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving, And blemish Caesar's triumph. Let him take thee, And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians: Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot Of all thy sex; most monster-like, be shown For poor'st diminutives, for doits; and let Patient Octavia plough thy visage up With her prepared nails. 'Tis well thou'rt gone, If it be well to live; but better 'twere Thou fell'st into my fury, for one death Might have prevented many. Eros, ho! The shirt of Nessus is upon me: teach me, Alcides, thou mine ancestor, thy rage: Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o' the moon; And with those hands, that grasp'd the heaviest club, Subdue my worthiest self. The witch shall die: To the young Roman boy she hath sold me, and I fall Under this plot; she dies for't. Eros, ho!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Help me, my women! O, he is more mad Than Telamon for his shield; the boar of Thessaly Was never so emboss'd.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: To the monument! There lock yourself, and send him word you are dead. The soul and body rive not more in parting Than greatness going off.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: To the monument! Mardian, go tell him I have slain myself; Say, that the last I spoke was 'Antony,' And word it, prithee, piteously: hence, Mardian, And bring me how he takes my death. To the monument!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Eros, thou yet behold'st me?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Ay, noble lord.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Sometimes we see a cloud that's dragonish; A vapour sometime like a bear or lion, A tower'd citadel, a pendent rock, A forked mountain, or blue promontory With trees upon't, that nod unto the world, And mock our eyes with air: thou hast seen these signs; They are black vesper's pageants.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Ay, my lord,

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: That which is now a horse, even with a thought The rack dislimns, and makes it indistinct, As water is in water.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: It does, my lord.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is Even such a body: here I am Antony: Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave. I made these wars for Egypt: and the queen,-- Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine; Which whilst it was mine had annex'd unto't A million more, now lost,--she, Eros, has Pack'd cards with Caesar, and false-play'd my glory Unto an enemy's triumph. Nay, weep not, gentle Eros; there is left us Ourselves to end ourselves. O! thy vile lady! She has robb'd me of my sword.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: No, Antony; My mistress loved thee, and her fortunes mingled With thine entirely.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Hence, saucy eunuch; peace! She hath betray'd me and shall die the death.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Death of one person can be paid but once, And that she has discharged: what thou wouldst do Is done unto thy hand: the last she spake Was 'Antony! most noble Antony!' Then in the midst a tearing groan did break The name of Antony; it was divided Between her heart and lips: she render'd life, Thy name so buried in her.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Dead, then?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Dead.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Unarm, Eros; the long day's task is done, And we must sleep. That thou depart'st hence safe, Does pay thy labour richly; go. Off, pluck off: The seven-fold shield of Ajax cannot keep The battery from my heart. O, cleave, my sides! Heart, once be stronger than thy continent, Crack thy frail case! Apace, Eros, apace. No more a soldier: bruised pieces, go; You have been nobly borne. From me awhile. I will o'ertake thee, Cleopatra, and Weep for my pardon. So it must be, for now All length is torture: since the torch is out, Lie down, and stray no farther: now all labour Mars what it does; yea, very force entangles Itself with strength: seal then, and all is done. Eros!--I come, my queen:--Eros!--Stay for me: Where souls do couch on flowers, we'll hand in hand, And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze: Dido and her AEneas shall want troops, And all the haunt be ours. Come, Eros, Eros!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What would my lord?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Since Cleopatra died, I have lived in such dishonour, that the gods Detest my baseness. I, that with my sword Quarter'd the world, and o'er green Neptune's back With ships made cities, condemn myself to lack The courage of a woman; less noble mind Than she which by her death our Caesar tells 'I am conqueror of myself.' Thou art sworn, Eros, That, when the exigent should come, which now Is come indeed, when I should see behind me The inevitable prosecution of Disgrace and horror, that, on my command, Thou then wouldst kill me: do't; the time is come: Thou strikest not me, 'tis Caesar thou defeat'st. Put colour in thy cheek.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The gods withhold me! Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts, Though enemy, lost aim, and could not?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Eros, Wouldst thou be window'd in great Rome and see Thy master thus with pleach'd arms, bending down His corrigible neck, his face subdued To penetrative shame, whilst the wheel'd seat Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded His baseness that ensued?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I would not see't.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Come, then; for with a wound I must be cured. Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn Most useful for thy country.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O, sir, pardon me!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: When I did make thee free, sworest thou not then To do this when I bade thee? Do it at once; Or thy precedent services are all But accidents unpurposed. Draw, and come.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Turn from me, then, that noble countenance, Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Lo thee!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: My sword is drawn.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Then let it do at once The thing why thou hast drawn it.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: My dear master, My captain, and my emperor, let me say, Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: 'Tis said, man; and farewell.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Farewell, great chief. Shall I strike now?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Now, Eros.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Why, there then: thus I do escape the sorrow Of Antony's death.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Thrice-nobler than myself! Thou teachest me, O valiant Eros, what I should, and thou couldst not. My queen and Eros Have by their brave instruction got upon me A nobleness in record: but I will be A bridegroom in my death, and run into't As to a lover's bed. Come, then; and, Eros, Thy master dies thy scholar: to do thus I learn'd of thee. How! not dead? not dead? The guard, ho! O, dispatch me!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What's the noise?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I have done my work in, friends: O, make an end Of what I have begun.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The star is fall'n.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: And time is at his period.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Alas, and woe!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Let him that loves me strike me dead.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Not I.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Nor I.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Nor any one.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly. This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings, Shall enter me with him.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Where's Antony?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: There, Diomed there.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Lives he? Wilt thou not answer, man?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Art thou there, Diomed? Draw thy sword, and give me Sufficing strokes for death.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Most absolute lord, My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: When did she send thee?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Now, my lord.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Where is she?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Lock'd in her monument. She had a prophesying fear Of what hath come to pass: for when she saw-- Which never shall be found--you did suspect She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead; But, fearing since how it might work, hath sent Me to proclaim the truth; and I am come, I dread, too late.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Too late, good Diomed: call my guard, I prithee.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What, ho, the emperor's guard! The guard, what, ho! Come, your lord calls!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides; 'Tis the last service that I shall command you.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear All your true followers out.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Most heavy day!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate To grace it with your sorrows: bid that welcome Which comes to punish us, and we punish it Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up: I have led you oft: carry me now, good friends, And have my thanks for all.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Be comforted, dear madam.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: No, I will not: All strange and terrible events are welcome, But comforts we despise; our size of sorrow, Proportion'd to our cause, must be as great As that which makes it. How now! is he dead?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: His death's upon him, but not dead. Look out o' the other side your monument; His guard have brought him thither.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O sun, Burn the great sphere thou movest in! darkling stand The varying shore o' the world. O Antony, Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help; Help, friends below; let's draw him hither.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Peace! Not Caesar's valour hath o'erthrown Antony, But Antony's hath triumph'd on itself.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: So it should be, that none but Antony Should conquer Antony; but woe 'tis so!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I am dying, Egypt, dying; only I here importune death awhile, until Of many thousand kisses the poor last I lay up thy lips.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I dare not, dear,-- Dear my lord, pardon,--I dare not, Lest I be taken: not the imperious show Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall Be brooch'd with me; if knife, drugs, serpents, have Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe: Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes And still conclusion, shall acquire no honour Demuring upon me. But come, come, Antony,-- Help me, my women,--we must draw thee up: Assist, good friends.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O, quick, or I am gone.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Here's sport indeed! How heavy weighs my lord! Our strength is all gone into heaviness, That makes the weight: had I great Juno's power, The strong-wing'd Mercury should fetch thee up, And set thee by Jove's side. Yet come a little,-- Wishes were ever fools,--O, come, come, come; And welcome, welcome! die where thou hast lived: Quicken with kissing: had my lips that power, Thus would I wear them out.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: A heavy sight!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I am dying, Egypt, dying: Give me some wine, and let me speak a little.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: No, let me speak; and let me rail so high, That the false housewife Fortune break her wheel, Provoked by my offence.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: One word, sweet queen: Of Caesar seek your honour, with your safety. O!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: They do not go together.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Gentle, hear me: None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: My resolution and my hands I'll trust; None about Caesar.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The miserable change now at my end Lament nor sorrow at; but please your thoughts In feeding them with those my former fortunes Wherein I lived, the greatest prince o' the world, The noblest; and do now not basely die, Not cowardly put off my helmet to My countryman,--a Roman by a Roman Valiantly vanquish'd. Now my spirit is going; I can no more.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Noblest of men, woo't die? Hast thou no care of me? shall I abide In this dull world, which in thy absence is No better than a sty? O, see, my women, The crown o' the earth doth melt. My lord! O, wither'd is the garland of the war, The soldier's pole is fall'n: young boys and girls Are level now with men; the odds is gone, And there is nothing left remarkable Beneath the visiting moon.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O, quietness, lady!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: She is dead too, our sovereign.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Lady!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Madam!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O madam, madam, madam!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Royal Egypt, Empress!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Peace, peace, Iras!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: No more, but e'en a woman, and commanded By such poor passion as the maid that milks And does the meanest chares. It were for me To throw my sceptre at the injurious gods; To tell them that this world did equal theirs Till they had stol'n our jewel. All's but naught; Patience is scottish, and impatience does Become a dog that's mad: then is it sin To rush into the secret house of death, Ere death dare come to us? How do you, women? What, what! good cheer! Why, how now, Charmian! My noble girls! Ah, women, women, look, Our lamp is spent, it's out! Good sirs, take heart: We'll bury him; and then, what's brave, what's noble, Let's do it after the high Roman fashion, And make death proud to take us. Come, away: This case of that huge spirit now is cold: Ah, women, women! come; we have no friend But resolution, and the briefest end.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield; Being so frustrate, tell him he mocks The pauses that he makes.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Caesar, I shall.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Wherefore is that? and what art thou that darest Appear thus to us?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I am call'd Dercetas; Mark Antony I served, who best was worthy Best to be served: whilst he stood up and spoke, He was my master; and I wore my life To spend upon his haters. If thou please To take me to thee, as I was to him I'll be to Caesar; if thou pleasest not, I yield thee up my life.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What is't thou say'st?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The breaking of so great a thing should make A greater crack: the round world Should have shook lions into civil streets, And citizens to their dens: the death of Antony Is not a single doom; in the name lay A moiety of the world.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: He is dead, Caesar: Not by a public minister of justice, Nor by a hired knife; but that self hand, Which writ his honour in the acts it did, Hath, with the courage which the heart did lend it, Splitted the heart. This is his sword; I robb'd his wound of it; behold it stain'd With his most noble blood.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Look you sad, friends? The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings To wash the eyes of kings.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: And strange it is, That nature must compel us to lament Our most persisted deeds.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: His taints and honours Waged equal with him.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: A rarer spirit never Did steer humanity: but you, gods, will give us Some faults to make us men. Caesar is touch'd.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: When such a spacious mirror's set before him, He needs must see himself.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O Antony! I have follow'd thee to this; but we do lance Diseases in our bodies: I must perforce Have shown to thee such a declining day, Or look on thine; we could not stall together In the whole world: but yet let me lament, With tears as sovereign as the blood of hearts, That thou, my brother, my competitor In top of all design, my mate in empire, Friend and companion in the front of war, The arm of mine own body, and the heart Where mine his thoughts did kindle,--that our stars, Unreconciliable, should divide Our equalness to this. Hear me, good friends-- But I will tell you at some meeter season: The business of this man looks out of him; We'll hear him what he says. Whence are you?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: A poor Egyptian yet. The queen my mistress, Confined in all she has, her monument, Of thy intents desires instruction, That she preparedly may frame herself To the way she's forced to.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Bid her have good heart: She soon shall know of us, by some of ours, How honourable and how kindly we Determine for her; for Caesar cannot live To be ungentle.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: So the gods preserve thee!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Come hither, Proculeius. Go and say, We purpose her no shame: give her what comforts The quality of her passion shall require, Lest, in her greatness, by some mortal stroke She do defeat us; for her life in Rome Would be eternal in our triumph: go, And with your speediest bring us what she says, And how you find of her.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Caesar, I shall.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Gallus, go you along. Where's Dolabella, To second Proculeius?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Dolabella!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Let him alone, for I remember now How he's employ'd: he shall in time be ready. Go with me to my tent; where you shall see How hardly I was drawn into this war; How calm and gentle I proceeded still In all my writings: go with me, and see What I can show in this.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: My desolation does begin to make A better life. 'Tis paltry to be Caesar; Not being Fortune, he's but Fortune's knave, A minister of her will: and it is great To do that thing that ends all other deeds; Which shackles accidents and bolts up change; Which sleeps, and never palates more the dug, The beggar's nurse and Caesar's.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt; And bids thee study on what fair demands Thou mean'st to have him grant thee.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What's thy name?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: My name is Proculeius.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Antony Did tell me of you, bade me trust you; but I do not greatly care to be deceived, That have no use for trusting. If your master Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him, That majesty, to keep decorum, must No less beg than a kingdom: if he please To give me conquer'd Egypt for my son, He gives me so much of mine own, as I Will kneel to him with thanks.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Be of good cheer; You're fall'n into a princely hand, fear nothing: Make your full reference freely to my lord, Who is so full of grace, that it flows over On all that need: let me report to him Your sweet dependency; and you shall find A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness, Where he for grace is kneel'd to.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Pray you, tell him I am his fortune's vassal, and I send him The greatness he has got. I hourly learn A doctrine of obedience; and would gladly Look him i' the face.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: This I'll report, dear lady. Have comfort, for I know your plight is pitied Of him that caused it.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: You see how easily she may be surprised: Guard her till Caesar come.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Royal queen!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O Cleopatra! thou art taken, queen:

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Quick, quick, good hands.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Hold, worthy lady, hold: Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this Relieved, but not betray'd.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What, of death too, That rids our dogs of languish?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Cleopatra, Do not abuse my master's bounty by The undoing of yourself: let the world see His nobleness well acted, which your death Will never let come forth.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Where art thou, death? Come hither, come! come, come, and take a queen Worthy many babes and beggars!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O, temperance, lady!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Sir, I will eat no meat, I'll not drink, sir; If idle talk will once be necessary, I'll not sleep neither: this mortal house I'll ruin, Do Caesar what he can. Know, sir, that I Will not wait pinion'd at your master's court; Nor once be chastised with the sober eye Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up And show me to the shouting varletry Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt Be gentle grave unto me! rather on Nilus' mud Lay me stark naked, and let the water-flies Blow me into abhorring! rather make My country's high pyramides my gibbet, And hang me up in chains!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: You do extend These thoughts of horror further than you shall Find cause in Caesar.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Proculeius, What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows, And he hath sent for thee: for the queen, I'll take her to my guard.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: So, Dolabella, It shall content me best: be gentle to her. To Caesar I will speak what you shall please, If you'll employ me to him.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Say, I would die.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Most noble empress, you have heard of me?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I cannot tell.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Assuredly you know me.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: No matter, sir, what I have heard or known. You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams; Is't not your trick?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I understand not, madam.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I dream'd there was an Emperor Antony: O, such another sleep, that I might see But such another man!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: If it might please ye,--

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: His face was as the heavens; and therein stuck A sun and moon, which kept their course, and lighted The little O, the earth.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Most sovereign creature,--

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: His legs bestrid the ocean: his rear'd arm Crested the world: his voice was propertied As all the tuned spheres, and that to friends; But when he meant to quail and shake the orb, He was as rattling thunder. For his bounty, There was no winter in't; an autumn 'twas That grew the more by reaping: his delights Were dolphin-like; they show'd his back above The element they lived in: in his livery Walk'd crowns and crownets; realms and islands were As plates dropp'd from his pocket.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Cleopatra!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Think you there was, or might be, such a man As this I dream'd of?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Gentle madam, no.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: You lie, up to the hearing of the gods. But, if there be, or ever were, one such, It's past the size of dreaming: nature wants stuff To vie strange forms with fancy; yet, to imagine And Antony, were nature's piece 'gainst fancy, Condemning shadows quite.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Hear me, good madam. Your loss is as yourself, great; and you bear it As answering to the weight: would I might never O'ertake pursued success, but I do feel, By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites My very heart at root.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I thank you, sir, Know you what Caesar means to do with me?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Nay, pray you, sir,--

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Though he be honourable,--

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: He'll lead me, then, in triumph?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Madam, he will; I know't.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Which is the Queen of Egypt?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: It is the emperor, madam.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Arise, you shall not kneel: I pray you, rise; rise, Egypt.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Sir, the gods Will have it thus; my master and my lord I must obey.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Take to you no hard thoughts: The record of what injuries you did us, Though written in our flesh, we shall remember As things but done by chance.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Sole sir o' the world, I cannot project mine own cause so well To make it clear; but do confess I have Been laden with like frailties which before Have often shamed our sex.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Cleopatra, know, We will extenuate rather than enforce: If you apply yourself to our intents, Which towards you are most gentle, you shall find A benefit in this change; but if you seek To lay on me a cruelty, by taking Antony's course, you shall bereave yourself Of my good purposes, and put your children To that destruction which I'll guard them from, If thereon you rely. I'll take my leave.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: And may, through all the world: 'tis yours; and we, Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shall Hang in what place you please. Here, my good lord.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: This is the brief of money, plate, and jewels, I am possess'd of: 'tis exactly valued; Not petty things admitted. Where's Seleucus?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Here, madam.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: This is my treasurer: let him speak, my lord, Upon his peril, that I have reserved To myself nothing. Speak the truth, Seleucus.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Madam, I had rather seal my lips, than, to my peril, Speak that which is not.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What have I kept back?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Enough to purchase what you have made known.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Nay, blush not, Cleopatra; I approve Your wisdom in the deed.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: See, Caesar! O, behold, How pomp is follow'd! mine will now be yours; And, should we shift estates, yours would be mine. The ingratitude of this Seleucus does Even make me wild: O slave, of no more trust Than love that's hired! What, goest thou back? thou shalt Go back, I warrant thee; but I'll catch thine eyes, Though they had wings: slave, soulless villain, dog! O rarely base!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Good queen, let us entreat you.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O Caesar, what a wounding shame is this, That thou, vouchsafing here to visit me, Doing the honour of thy lordliness To one so meek, that mine own servant should Parcel the sum of my disgraces by Addition of his envy! Say, good Caesar, That I some lady trifles have reserved, Immoment toys, things of such dignity As we greet modern friends withal; and say, Some nobler token I have kept apart For Livia and Octavia, to induce Their mediation; must I be unfolded With one that I have bred? The gods! it smites me Beneath the fall I have. Prithee, go hence; Or I shall show the cinders of my spirits Through the ashes of my chance: wert thou a man, Thou wouldst have mercy on me.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Forbear, Seleucus.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Be it known, that we, the greatest, are misthought For things that others do; and, when we fall, We answer others' merits in our name, Are therefore to be pitied.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Cleopatra, Not what you have reserved, nor what acknowledged, Put we i' the roll of conquest: still be't yours, Bestow it at your pleasure; and believe, Caesar's no merchant, to make prize with you Of things that merchants sold. Therefore be cheer'd; Make not your thoughts your prisons: no, dear queen; For we intend so to dispose you as Yourself shall give us counsel. Feed, and sleep: Our care and pity is so much upon you, That we remain your friend; and so, adieu.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: My master, and my lord!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Not so. Adieu.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: He words me, girls, he words me, that I should not Be noble to myself: but, hark thee, Charmian.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Finish, good lady; the bright day is done, And we are for the dark.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Hie thee again: I have spoke already, and it is provided; Go put it to the haste.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Madam, I will.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Where is the queen?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Behold, sir.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Dolabella!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Madam, as thereto sworn by your command, Which my love makes religion to obey, I tell you this: Caesar through Syria Intends his journey; and within three days You with your children will he send before: Make your best use of this: I have perform'd Your pleasure and my promise.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Dolabella, I shall remain your debtor.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I your servant, Adieu, good queen; I must attend on Caesar.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Farewell, and thanks. Now, Iras, what think'st thou? Thou, an Egyptian puppet, shalt be shown In Rome, as well as I mechanic slaves With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers, shall Uplift us to the view; in their thick breaths, Rank of gross diet, shall be enclouded, And forced to drink their vapour.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: The gods forbid!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Nay, 'tis most certain, Iras: saucy lictors Will catch at us, like strumpets; and scald rhymers Ballad us out o' tune: the quick comedians Extemporally will stage us, and present Our Alexandrian revels; Antony Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness I' the posture of a whore.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O the good gods!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Nay, that's certain.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I'll never see 't; for, I am sure, my nails Are stronger than mine eyes.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Why, that's the way To fool their preparation, and to conquer Their most absurd intents. Now, Charmian! Show me, my women, like a queen: go fetch My best attires: I am again for Cydnus, To meet Mark Antony: sirrah Iras, go. Now, noble Charmian, we'll dispatch indeed; And, when thou hast done this chare, I'll give thee leave To play till doomsday. Bring our crown and all. Wherefore's this noise?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Here is a rural fellow That will not be denied your highness presence: He brings you figs.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Let him come in. What poor an instrument May do a noble deed! he brings me liberty. My resolution's placed, and I have nothing Of woman in me: now from head to foot I am marble-constant; now the fleeting moon No planet is of mine.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: This is the man.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Avoid, and leave him. Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there, That kills and pains not?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Truly, I have him: but I would not be the party that should desire you to touch him, for his biting is immortal; those that do die of it do seldom or never recover.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Rememberest thou any that have died on't?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Very many, men and women too. I heard of one of them no longer than yesterday: a very honest woman, but something given to lie; as a woman should not do, but in the way of honesty: how she died of the biting of it, what pain she felt: truly, she makes a very good report o' the worm; but he that will believe all that they say, shall never be saved by half that they do: but this is most fallible, the worm's an odd worm.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Get thee hence; farewell.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: I wish you all joy of the worm.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Farewell.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: You must think this, look you, that the worm will do his kind.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Ay, ay; farewell.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Look you, the worm is not to be trusted but in the keeping of wise people; for, indeed, there is no goodness in worm.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Take thou no care; it shall be heeded.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Very good. Give it nothing, I pray you, for it is not worth the feeding.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Will it eat me?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: You must not think I am so simple but I know the devil himself will not eat a woman: I know that a woman is a dish for the gods, if the devil dress her not. But, truly, these same whoreson devils do the gods great harm in their women; for in every ten that they make, the devils mar five.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Well, get thee gone; farewell.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Yes, forsooth: I wish you joy o' the worm.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Give me my robe, put on my crown; I have Immortal longings in me: now no more The juice of Egypt's grape shall moist this lip: Yare, yare, good Iras; quick. Methinks I hear Antony call; I see him rouse himself To praise my noble act; I hear him mock The luck of Caesar, which the gods give men To excuse their after wrath: husband, I come: Now to that name my courage prove my title! I am fire and air; my other elements I give to baser life. So; have you done? Come then, and take the last warmth of my lips. Farewell, kind Charmian; Iras, long farewell. Have I the aspic in my lips? Dost fall? If thou and nature can so gently part, The stroke of death is as a lover's pinch, Which hurts, and is desired. Dost thou lie still? If thus thou vanishest, thou tell'st the world It is not worth leave-taking.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain; that I may say, The gods themselves do weep!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: This proves me base: If she first meet the curled Antony, He'll make demand of her, and spend that kiss Which is my heaven to have. Come, thou mortal wretch, With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate Of life at once untie: poor venomous fool Be angry, and dispatch. O, couldst thou speak, That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass Unpolicied!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O eastern star!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Peace, peace! Dost thou not see my baby at my breast, That sucks the nurse asleep?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O, break! O, break!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle,-- O Antony!--Nay, I will take thee too. What should I stay--

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: In this vile world? So, fare thee well. Now boast thee, death, in thy possession lies A lass unparallel'd. Downy windows, close; And golden Phoebus never be beheld Of eyes again so royal! Your crown's awry; I'll mend it, and then play.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Where is the queen?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Speak softly, wake her not.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Caesar hath sent--

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Too slow a messenger. O, come apace, dispatch! I partly feel thee.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Approach, ho! All's not well: Caesar's beguiled.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: There's Dolabella sent from Caesar; call him.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: What work is here! Charmian, is this well done?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: It is well done, and fitting for a princess Descended of so many royal kings. Ah, soldier!

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: How goes it here?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: All dead.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Caesar, thy thoughts Touch their effects in this: thyself art coming To see perform'd the dreaded act which thou So sought'st to hinder.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O sir, you are too sure an augurer; That you did fear is done.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Bravest at the last, She levell'd at our purposes, and, being royal, Took her own way. The manner of their deaths? I do not see them bleed.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Who was last with them?

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: A simple countryman, that brought her figs: This was his basket.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Poison'd, then.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O Caesar, This Charmian lived but now; she stood and spake: I found her trimming up the diadem On her dead mistress; tremblingly she stood And on the sudden dropp'd.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: O noble weakness! If they had swallow'd poison, 'twould appear By external swelling: but she looks like sleep, As she would catch another Antony In her strong toil of grace.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Here, on her breast, There is a vent of blood and something blown: The like is on her arm.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: This is an aspic's trail: and these fig-leaves Have slime upon them, such as the aspic leaves Upon the caves of Nile.

Play: The Tragedy of Antony and Cleopatra
Text: Most probable That so she died; for her physician tells me She hath pursued conclusions infinite Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed; And bear her women from the monument: She shall be buried by her Antony: No grave upon the earth shall clip in it A pair so famous. High events as these Strike those that make them; and their story is No less in pity than his glory which Brought them to be lamented. Our army shall In solemn show attend this funeral; And then to Rome. Come, Dolabella, see High order in this great solemnity.
